docs.lead_paragraph: The Mayor of Morristown has announced that he is preparing a domestic-partnership ordinance to provide health benefits to domestic partners of the town's 200 employees. Morristown would be the first municipality in the state to provide benefits to domestic partners, including lesbians and gay men, under the ordinance announced Tuesday night by Mayor Jay Delaney at the town's reorganization meeting. The state's civil rights law specifically bans discrimination on the basis of sexual preference, but the state government does not offer benefits to domestic partners of its employees.
docs.abstract: Morristown, NJ, Mayor Jay Delaney announces that he is preparing domestic-partnership ordinance to provide health benefits to domestic partners of town's 200 employees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A PERSON can live blissfully for 37 years without a coffee table, then one day suddenly look at the big empty area in the center of the living-room rug and realize: it's all wrong. This epiphany occurred at a party recently, as I watched my guests awkwardly balancing plates of food on their knees. Soon after, I embarked on a search for the perfect coffee table with the sort of zealous fervor usually associated with a religious convert.

headline.main: Web Lust: More Money, More Stuff

docs.abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on lusting for goods sold via Internet and trying to convince personal finance Web site that she can afford them; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of a Federal advisory commission today proposed radical changes in Medicare, recommending that the Government, instead of paying separately for each medical service, offer a fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to buy private health insurance. Members of the commission agreed to draft a detailed proposal for such changes, along the lines recommended by the chairman, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, and the co-chairman, Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California. The goal is to update Medicare to make it similar to the commercial health insurance market, to offer more choices to beneficiaries and to keep Medicare from going bankrupt.

headline.main: Federal Panel Urges Overhaul of Medicare Payment System

docs.lead_paragraph: Rather than seeing his convincing re-election victory as a mandate for daring new initiatives, Gov. George E. Pataki seemed determined today to give New Yorkers more of what so many of them liked the first time around. He could have used his annual address to the Legislature to try and set his second term apart from his first. He could have made bold promises and electric commitments. But the Governor instead hewed to his longstanding priorities: curbing state spending, cutting taxes and toughening the criminal justice system.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton's proposal to use tax credits to help about two million disabled Americans, many of whom depend on relatives for long-term care, includes some innovative ideas, but it also has some serious problems. John Rother, public policy director of the American Association of Retired Persons, applauds the program for ''providing overdue recognition and support for caregivers.''

headline.main: Economic Scene; The President's plan on tax credits for the disabled has new ideas but also serious problems.

docs.abstract: Michael M Weinstein, in Economic Scene column, contends that Pres Clinton's proposal to use tax credits to help about two million disabled Americans includes some innovative ideas, but it also has some serious problems; cites contention of critics that proposal skips over most of poor, provides small financial protection for middle-class families and largely overlooks potential for private insurance to handle problem (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 U.S. Says It Had Spies Among Inspectors in Iraq United States officials said American spies had worked undercover on teams of United Nations inspectors ferreting out secret weapons programs in Iraq. American officials did not say how many American intelligence officers served on the commission nor describe their precise roles. Iraq has long condemned the inspectors as tools of American intelligence. A1 France Criticizes Air Strikes France's Prime Minister Lionel Jospin criticized American and British air strikes against Iraq in a French newspaper interview and said that France would propose ways for ending the impasse with Saddam Hussein. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL Iraq's Arab Relations Sour In Wake of U.S. Attack A bitter war of words has followed last month's American-led attack on Iraq, leaving the Government in Baghdad increasingly at odds with other governments in the Arab world. Egypt has responded with particular scorn, all but calling for the ouster of Saddam Hussein. A1 American warplanes fired on, but missed, Iraqi jets that were reported to have penetrated the ''no flight'' zone over southern Iraq. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Clinton Seeks Aid for Care of Those With Chronic Ills'' (news article, Jan. 4): One way to encourage people to buy long-term health care insurance is by giving them tax credits. The largest tax credits would be based on a taxpayer's premiums and taxable income. Credits would go to those with the lowest incomes: those who are the likeliest candidates for Medicaid. Long-term health care insurance could thus play a role in reducing Medicaid dependency.
docs.abstract: Helen Jacobson letter holds one way to encourage people to buy long-term health care insurance is by giving them tax credits (Jan 4 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of President Clinton's appointees to a Federal advisory commission studying the future of Medicare said today that new taxes or other revenues would be required to keep the program intact for millions of baby boomers. The comments by the commissioner, Bruce C. Vladeck, injected an explosive new element into the panel's deliberations. From 1993 to 1997, Mr. Vladeck was administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare. He talks frequently with Clinton Administration officials and Democrats in Congress about health policy.

headline.main: Panelist Says New Taxes Are Needed For Medicare

docs.abstract: Bruce C Vladeck, one of Pres Clinton's appointees to Federal advisory commission studying future of Medicare, says that new taxes or other revenues will be required to keep program intact for millions of baby boomers (M)
